title: Arizona Voters Choose Gifford's Replacement
content:
TUCSON — Ron Barber , whom former Representative Gabrielle Giffords picked as her successor , defeated his Republican rival on Tuesday in a closely followed special election seen by many political strategists as testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive races .
Mr. Barber ’ s win over Jesse Kelly was largely secured by voters in Pima County , the largest of the four counties that make up the district and also home to Tucson , its base and Ms. Giffords ’ s former hometown . Turnout there and in most others of the district was high for a special election , reflecting the significance of the race and Ms. Giffords ’ s draw on voters .
With 100 percent of precincts reporting , Mr. Barber , a Democrat , had secured roughly 53 percent of the vote . Mr. Kelly had 45 percent , while Charlie Manolakis , the Green Party candidate , came at a distant third , with 2.3 percent .
It was a contest full of emotion , making results in an already volatile district even harder to predict . Republicans hold a slight edge in the Southern Arizona district , but many of its Republican voters espouse liberal views on social issues , just like many of the independents , who make up 30 percent of the electorate . The district also picked Ms. Giffords , a Democrat , to succeed its longtime representative , Jim Kolbe , a Republican , after his retirement in 2007 .
Ms. Giffords resigned in January , a year after she was shot in the head when a gunman opened fire outside a supermarket here , where she had been greeting constituents . Mr. Barber , one of her top aides , was among the 12 others who were injured . Six people died .
The race attracted more money than the average special election , most of it coming from political action committees — and most of it going to Mr. Kelly , who had come close to defeating Ms. Giffords in 2010 . Through mailings , mostly , Republicans sought to establish connections between Mr. Barber and President Obama , who is not widely popular among voters in Southern Arizona .

Photo

TUCSON — Ron Barber, whom former Representative Gabrielle Giffords picked as her successor, defeated his Republican rival on Tuesday in a closely followed special election seen by many political strategists as testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive races.

Mr. Barber’s win over Jesse Kelly was largely secured by voters in Pima County, the largest of the four counties that make up the district and also home to Tucson, its base and Ms. Giffords’s former hometown. Turnout there and in most others of the district was high for a special election, reflecting the significance of the race and Ms. Giffords’s draw on voters.

With 100 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Barber, a Democrat, had secured roughly 53 percent of the vote. Mr. Kelly had 45 percent, while Charlie Manolakis, the Green Party candidate, came at a distant third, with 2.3 percent.

It was a contest full of emotion, making results in an already volatile district even harder to predict. Republicans hold a slight edge in the Southern Arizona district, but many of its Republican voters espouse liberal views on social issues, just like many of the independents, who make up 30 percent of the electorate. The district also picked Ms. Giffords, a Democrat, to succeed its longtime representative, Jim Kolbe, a Republican, after his retirement in 2007.

Advertisement Continue reading the main story

Ms. Giffords resigned in January, a year after she was shot in the head when a gunman opened fire outside a supermarket here, where she had been greeting constituents. Mr. Barber, one of her top aides, was among the 12 others who were injured. Six people died.

Photo

The race attracted more money than the average special election, most of it coming from political action committees — and most of it going to Mr. Kelly, who had come close to defeating Ms. Giffords in 2010. Through mailings, mostly, Republicans sought to establish connections between Mr. Barber and President Obama, who is not widely popular among voters in Southern Arizona.
